summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team's requests. The government argues against disclosing witness names 11 months before trial and against court intervention in her detention conditions at the MDC. It details the discovery production timeline and disputes defense claims of inadequate access.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330), accused of crimes related to Jeffrey Epstein. Her defense team is requesting early witness disclosure and challenging her detention conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The government's letter is addressed to her, opposing the defense's motions.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the government's opposition letter, representing the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding. The government is submitting this letter to Judge Nathan opposing motions filed by Maxwell's defense.

events.title: Protective Order Docketed
events.description: The protective order governing discovery in the case was posted to the court docket, enabling the government to begin discovery production.

events.title: First Discovery Production
events.description: The government produced an initial discovery batch totaling more than 12,000 pages to the defense.

events.title: Second Discovery Production
events.description: The government made a second discovery production, totaling more than 150,000 pages, principally consisting of financial records.

events.title: Maxwell Receives First Discovery
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell received her personal copy of the government's first discovery production at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

events.title: Scheduled Trial
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled for July 2021, approximately 11 months from the date of this letter.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government had produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense within two weeks of the protective order being docketed.
The government strongly opposed disclosing the names of victim-witnesses 11 months before trial, citing legal precedent and a desire to protect victim privacy.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) planned to provide Maxwell extended access to discovery materials from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. daily, subject to operational constraints.
The government expressed concern that Maxwell's defense counsel had referenced receiving sealed discovery materials from the criminal case in a public civil court filing.
The defense's request for court intervention in Maxwell's detention conditions was deemed premature, as BOP was conducting an individualized assessment for her housing and security.
